questions.question_text: What are the circular lines in each map called? And do you know what the lines radiating out of the two poles are called? (Hint: you studied them in the previous chapter, but here they are presented differently.)
hints: Refer to geographical grid lines
Think of lines of latitude and longitude
Observe the blue areas in both hemisphere maps
Compare Northern vs Southern Hemisphere

questions.question_text: What do you think could be the approximate proportion of water to land in the Northern Hemisphere? And in the Southern Hemisphere? Discuss in groups.
hints: Estimate from visual observation of maps
Consider that Earth's surface is ~71% water

questions.question_text: Are all the oceans connected with one another, or are there separations between them?
hints: Look at the world map showing oceans
Consider if water can flow between them

questions.question_text: Locate the five oceans and, in the table below, mark the hemisphere or hemispheres they belong to. Northern Hemisphere, Southern Hemisphere: Pacific Ocean, Atlantic Ocean, Indian Ocean, Southern Ocean, Arctic Ocean
hints: Use world map reference
Check which hemispheres each ocean spans

questions.question_text: Counting the numbers of squares, name the largest continent and the smallest.
hints: Refer to continent size diagram
Count squares for each continent

questions.question_text: Which one is larger — North America or South America? Africa or North America? Antarctica or Australia?
hints: Compare square counts in diagram
Use visual comparison of sizes

questions.question_text: Re-colour the diagram by having a single colour for Europe and Asia and rename the result as 'Eurasia'. Compare its size with South America's.
hints: Combine Europe and Asia squares
Compare total with South America

questions.question_text: Write down the list of continents from the smallest to the largest.
hints: Arrange all seven continents by size
Use square counts from diagram

questions.question_text: Explain the following terms: (a) Continent (b) Ocean (c) Island
hints: Refer to definitions in chapter
Use your own words based on understanding

questions.question_text: Let us draw – Without looking at the maps in this chapter, draw the continents free hand on a sheet of paper and colour them. Then compare your drawing with the map of oceans and continents in the chapter.
hints: Recall shapes of continents from memory
Focus on relative positions and sizes

questions.question_text: Let us do – On the outline map of the world given below, label all the continents and oceans.
hints: Use knowledge of continent and ocean names
Refer to world map for correct placement

questions.question_text: Solve this crossword with clues: Across: 1. Abundantly produced by the oceans, 3. A large expanse of landmass, 5. The smallest continent, 6. A large continent of which India is a part, 8. A major source of pollution of the oceans, 10. The coldest continent. Down: 2. The largest island on Earth, 4. A huge destructive wave from the ocean, 7. The largest body of water on the Earth, 9. A landmass (but not a continent) surrounded by the sea or ocean.
hints: Use chapter content for answers
Think of key terms learned
